_exec_summary.SummaryText:
40 CFR Part 68.155

Lake Hefner Water Treatment Plant (WTP) has adopted this Risk Management Program to implement
40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 68, the federal requirements regulating risk management of
extremely hazardous chemicals. This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the
consequences of, a catastrophic release by implementing policies and procedures for the management
of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance, and the other requirements
addressed in the federal standard.

This Executive Summary includes information required under 40 CFR 68.155.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Department implements a scheduled preventive maintenance
program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard
Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their
work safely and efficiently and provide immediate corrective response to any accidents.
Lake Hefner WTP staff are trained to respond in the event of a chemical release incident. Emergency
response to accidental releases is also coordinated with the Oklahoma City Police and Fire Departments
and State and Local Emergency Response Centers.

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances
Lake Hefner WTP utilizes chlorine (regulated substance) as a disinfectant in the drinking water
treatment process.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
A Process Hazard Analysis as well as written process safety information has been developed to enable
personnel to identify and understand the hazards posed by processes involving extremely hazardous
chemicals. Process safety information includes chlorine information, technology of the process
information, and equipment information.
The City of Oklahoma City Utilities Engineering Division verifies that City-owned

WTPs comply with
applicable codes and standards and with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices
(through review of engineering standards for construction projects).
A Hazard Review/Process Hazard Analysis was completed for this Risk Management Plan (RMP)/Process
Safety Management Plan (PSMP) that documents the process and findings to minimize or eliminate
hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and reduce
the likelihood of exposure to chlorine.
Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for each
hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health
considerations, and safety systems and their functions. All employees involved in working with and
around the chlorine system are trained annually in process and safety procedures, including emergency
response.

The mechanical integrity of chlorine process equipment is documented and maintained through
maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has
been established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine system.
A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and
construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard
analysis recommendations have been resolved.

A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation program
is to ensure that a strong Risk Management Program is maintained, implemented, and followed by
appropriate personnel. Staff has developed a formal documented system to manage incident
investigations and follow up. Each incident from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries,
evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage will be investigated and an
incident investigation report filed in the R

¿ Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes
at the stationary source and ensure that employees are informed of changes
Plant emergency procedures are maintained at the location for the chlorine stationary source. WTP
personnel are trained to take action to control a minor release. Trained personnel will attempt to
control a release within their capability. However, in the event that the release is beyond the control of
the operators, they would immediately call 911.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
The WTP planned changes to improve safety include conducting a review of RMP elements on an annual
basis and conduct and document annual drills that include a hotwash for employee feedback.

MP.

Lake Hefner WTP management staff are committed to involving employees, or their representatives, in
supporting the elements of the RMP/PSMP. The following elements involve employee participation
regarding the RMP/PSMP:
¿ Involve employees in the hazard review, Compliance Audits, and RMP/PSMP reviews and updates
¿ Provide employee access to the RMP/PSMP
¿ Present an overview of RMP/PSMP requirements to staff annually
¿ Involve employees in the development and updating of training
¿ Involve employees in an incident investigation

An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated chlorine
process has been implemented at the WTP. Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or
adjacent to the chlorine process are instructed in the hazards of the materials onsite, and
documentation is maintained on contractor understanding of training provided as described in the
RMP/PSMP. In addition, emphasis is placed on knowing how to respond in event of emergency. The
WTP chlorine system technology is not confidential and any information regarding the process or
process chemistry is available for review in the RMP.

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 years from the chlorine covered processes that
resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental
damage. There was one accidental release of anhydrous ammonia (this process is no longer present at
the Plant) in 2015.

Emergency Response Program
The RMP Emergency Response Plan for the WTP includes the following elements:
¿ Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental
releases
¿ Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental
human exposures
¿ Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated
substance
